August 6, 1956
Mr, Colgate W. Darden, President
University of Virginia
Charlottesville, Virginia
Dear President Daroen:
We are very pleased to see that your institution has been
GRANTED A CP FOR A NEW EDUCATIONAL STATION. THE FORCES OF
EDUCATIONAL BROADCASTING ARE GROWING STRONGER EVERY DAY, AND,
AS THE ASSOCIATION OF EDUCATIONAL STATIONS IN THE UNITED STATES,
WE FEEL THAT YOU WILL BE INTERESTED IN LEARNING SOMETHING ABOUT
OUR ORGANIZATION AND THE SERVICES IT PROVIDES TO MEMBERS. IN¬
CIDENTALLY, BETTER THAN 90% OF ALL EDUCATIONAL RADIO AND TELE¬
VISION STATIONS IN THE UNITED STATES BELONG TO THE NAEB.
I AM ENCLOSING SOME MATERIAL WHICH WILL GIVE YOU MORE DETAILS
ABOUT THE ASSOCIATION, AND UNDER SEPARATE COVER AM SENDING SAMPLES
OF THE REPORTS, SURVEYS AND OTHER SERVICES WE REGULARLY MAKE
AVAILABLE TO MEMBER STATIONS.
Annual dues in the Association, including a subscription to our
monthly Newsletter and the above mentioned materials, are based
on rated transmitter power, as follows:
Class A - 5 kw and over - #50*00
Class B - 1 - 4.9 kw - 25.00
Class C - Less than 1 kw- 15.00
In addition to the above, member stations enjoy the benefits of
our Placement Service, legal counsel, help in meeting day-to-day
problems, the opportunity to meet, in seminars, conferences and
CONVENTIONS, WITH OTHER EDUCATIONAL BROADCASTERS TO CONSIOER
MUTUAL PROBLEMS, AND, FOR THE PAYMENT OF AN ADDITIONAL ASSESS¬
MENT FEE, THE USE OF OUR TAPE NETWORK.
The NAEB Network, which distributes over 400 hours of programming,
VIA TAPE RECORDING, PER YEAR, IS OPEN ONLY TO MEMBERS OF THE
Association. Through the Network you have an opportunity to
BROADCAST SOME OF THE BEST EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS FROM ALL OVER THE
COUNTRY AS WELL AS A CHANCE TO HAVE SOME OF YOUR BETTER PROGRAMS
RECEIVE WIDER DISTRIBUTION. In ADDITION, BEING ABLE TO RELY ON
the Network for eight or more hours of programming per week per¬
mits YOUR STAFF TO SPENO MORE TIME ON THE DEVELOPMENT OF OUT¬
STANDING PROGRAMS.
